docs.lead_paragraph: YOU take it all with a grain of salt when you read your daily horoscope or the advice columns. But advice dispensed on the couch by a trained psychologist should carry more weight, right? Sure, but watch it: Even therapists with the best credentials can be all over the map. That's clear from a new book, ''Escaping the Advice Trap'' (Andrews McMeel), by Wendy M. Williams and Stephen J. Ceci, psychologists at Cornell University. Drawing on 59 difficult cases, they gave pertinent details to at least two psychologists with doctorates and asked what they thought. Sometimes the answers were similar, but other times they diverged wildly -- indicating that all advice is subjective, determined by values and culture, even when dispensed by experts.

headline.main: Word for Word/Therapy; You Are Getting Very Confused: Psychologists' Split Decisions

docs.abstract: Excerpts from Cornell University psychologists Wendy M Williams and Stephen J Ceci new book Escaping the Advice Trap; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Here's a bold and exciting idea in local news: artificial insemination of the anchor. Sounds icky, but the concept has been a ratings success for WCAU in Philadelphia, an NBC affiliate that has turned the pregnancy of Renee Chenault -- anchorwoman and single-mom hopeful (pictured) -- into an up-close-and-personal saga that will, of course, go on for months.
docs.abstract: WCAU, Philadelphia, has made rating success of stories on artificial insemination and pregnancy of anchorwoman Renee Chenault; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY strike without warning, bringing terror to an apartment in Algeria, a Chinese shop in Indonesia, a squalid refugee encampment in Africa or a Balkan farming village under siege. They are shadowy men with causes so blinding and hatreds so deep that they have transformed modern warfare into orgies of primordial savagery -- raping, brutalizing, humiliating, slashing and hacking women and girls to death. More civilians than soldiers are being maimed and killed in the wars of nationalism and ethnicity that are the hallmark of the century's end, wars fought in neighborhoods rather than battlefields.

headline.main: THE WORLD: Violation; An Old Scourge of War Becomes Its Latest Crime

docs.abstract: Barbara Crossette article contends that rape was used as tactic of warfare in Bosnia, Rwanda and other countries to terrorize and humiliate civilian populations; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Even in the friendly crowd at an afternoon coffee, where three generations of women were gathered around a silver punch bowl, talking politics in between bites of ham roll, the Senate candidate Blanche Lambert Lincoln heard the usual question: ''Do you see hubby and the babies at all?'' The Democratic candidate smiled and explained, again, how her husband was really supportive and her 2-year-old twins, Bennett and Reece, were doing fine. In 1996, just after learning she was having twins, Mrs. Lincoln announced that she would leave the House of Representatives to be at home full time. Now that she wants to go back to Washington with a promotion, her mothering has become an issue in the race.

headline.main: No Escaping Motherhood on Campaign Trail

docs.abstract: Mothering has emerged as election issue for Democrat Blanche Lambert Lincoln, who left House in 1996 to be at home full-time with her twins, now 2, and is front-runner for Senate in Arkansas; she and her staff say they sense concern, particularly among older women, over how she will juggle duties; she has made her children focal point of campaign and issue seems to be helping her, particularly with younger women; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Last fall the Supreme Court of South Carolina, in a bizarre 3-to-2 decision, ruled that a viable fetus is legally a ''child'' and that therefore a pregnant woman who does something detrimental to the fetus can be prosecuted for child abuse. Malissa Ann Crawley smoked cocaine when she was pregnant in 1991. It doesn't matter that her son from that pregnancy is now 6 years old and quite healthy, or that Ms. Crawley overcame her drug habit, obtained employment and has successfully been raising three children. Those kids are now with relatives and Ms. Crawley is in prison because of a criminal justice policy that is irrational and extreme, and law enforcers who frequently are merciless.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column assails South Carolina Supreme Court ruling that viable fetus is legally 'child' and that pregnant woman who does something detrimental to fetus can be prosecuted for child abuse; contends that Malissa Ann Crawley, who smoked cocaine when she was pregnant in 1991, has begun serving five-year prison sentence because of criminal justice policy that is irrational and extreme (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the South Korean economy boomed, so did Son Kyoung Suk's career. As a clothing designer at Shinsegae Department Store, she was steadily given more responsibility and promoted to become a buyer, a job usually reserved for men. Then when South Korea's economy burst, so did Mrs. Son's career. The company needed to slash costs, and so her department decided to cut her position and those of five other women.

headline.main: With Asia's Economies Shrinking, Women Are Being Squeezed Out

docs.abstract: With Asia's Economies Shrinking, Women Are Being Squeezed Out**Second of two articles in series, The Human Crisis, discusses how Asian financial crisis has been special disaster for women; Asia's long economic boom had been chipping away at gender inequities and creating new opportunities for women, but financial crisis has reversed process; job and educational opportunities are narrowing again for them in Indonesia, Japan, Thailand and South Korea; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to love, sex and friendship, do birds of a feather flock together? Or is it more important that opposites attract? The argument is so old that even Aristotle mentioned evidence for both sides. Recently, a new chapter has been opened by researchers who say that for at least one type of gene people find difference sexy and sameness boring -- and that they use their noses to tell which is which.

headline.main: Studies Explore Love and the Sweaty T-Shirt

docs.abstract: Researchers seeking answer to age-old mystery about what causes romantic attachment between people find that for at least one type of gene, people find difference sexy and sameness boring and that they use their noses to tell which is which; genes in question instruct cells to make proteins of Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC), one of immune system's key markers of identity; suggestion that different MHC genes might be linked to different odors led to work on laboratory animals that establisehd that animals prefer mates that were different in their MHC genes; in latest study, involving humans, men's sweaty shirts were offered to women; women dissimilar to particular male's MHC perceived his odor as more pleasant than women whose MHC is more similar to that of test man; photos (M)
docs.snippet: WHEN it comes to love, sex and friendship, do birds of a feather flock together? Or is it more important that opposites attract? The argument is so old that even Aristotle mentioned evidence for both sides.    Recently, a new chapter has been opened...
